Header Files</a></span></dt><dt><span class="section"><a href="#_compile_time_version_detection">5.2. Compile-time Version Detection</a></span></dt><dt><span class="section"><a href="#_constants_and_implementation_supplied_values">5.3. Constants and Implementation-Supplied Values</a></span></dt></dl></dd><dt><span class="section"><a href="#_conformance_testing_for_implementers">6. Conformance Testing for Implementers</a></span></dt></dl></div><div class="section" title="1. Overview"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h2 class="title" style="clear: both"><a id="_overview"></a>1. Overview</h2></div></div></div><p>This document describes GEIS, an interface between an application and an
underlying gesture recognition system.</p><p>A GEIS implementation provides a mechanism for recognizing user interface
gestures on various configurable devices and for propagating those recognized
gestures to subscribed applications.</p><div class="section" title="1.1. Gestures"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_gestures"></a>1.1. Gestures</h3></div></div></div><p>A <span class="emphasis"><em>gesture</em></span> is a defined set of particular movements of pointing devices.  GEIS
provides no interpretation of gestures, only recognition and propagation.</p><p>Because gestures can be defined to have global meaning as well as local meaning,
it makes sense that gesture recognition be provided by the system rather than be
included as a library by a particular application or toolkit.  This allows, for
example, a set of gestures to be defined for the window manager in use on a
display to receive gesture events even when another application is in the
foreground and receiving the input.</p></div></div><div class="section" title="2. GEIS Operation"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h2 class="title" style="clear: both"><a id="_geis_operation"></a>2. GEIS Operation</h2></div></div></div><p>The purpose of GEIS is intended to provide a consistent and stable application
programming interface for gesture recognition and propagation on multiple target
platforms (for example, Linux, Unix, and Windows), multiple target input
devices (for example mice, touch pads, mutitouch touchscreens, tables, nunchuks),
and multiple gesture recognition engines.  Different gesture engines may be
available on the same platform.</p><p>A number of basic types are defined for portability between various underlying
display, input, and operating systems.</p><div class="section" title="2.1. GEIS Basic Types"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_geis_basic_types"></a>2.1. GEIS Basic Types</h3></div></div></div><p><code class="literal">GeisBoolean</code> is an integral type representing a boolean value and should only
hold the values <code class="literal">GEIS_TRUE</code> (1) and <code class="literal">GEIS_FALSE</code> (0).</p><p><code class="literal">GeisInt</code> is an integral type large enough to hold any integral gesture attribute
value which may be represented on the native platform.  This may includes
bitmasks, enumerants, integers, handles, and so forth.</p><p><code class="literal">GeisFloat</code> is a floating-point type which can represent floating-point valued
gesture attributes,</p><p><code class="literal">GeisString</code> is a C-style zero-terminated string of characters in some character
set.  A <code class="literal">GeisString</code> is a read-only string and does not have to be freed or
disposed of by the caller.</p></div><div class="section" title="2.2. GEIS Instances"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_geis_instances"></a>2.2. GEIS Instances</h3></div></div></div><p>An application may need to support different sets of gestures from different
input devices or associated with different regions of the same device.  For this
reason, GEIS provides for one or more distinct connections to the underlying
gesture engine.  The instances are distinguished by a GeisInstance object.  All
gesture types and gesture instances IDs are in a namespace associated with the
GeisInstance and are not guaranteed to be system wide unique.</p><div class="section" title="2.2.1. Threading and Concurrency"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h4 class="title"><a id="_threading_and_concurrency"></a>2.2.1. Threading and Concurrency</h4></div></div></div><p>The GEIS API does not specify threading, reentrancy, or concurrency attributes.
The implementation must supply detailed documentation on these aspects.</p></div><div class="section" title="2.2.2. Input Devices"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h4 class="title"><a id="_input_devices"></a>2.2.2. Input Devices</h4></div></div></div><p>The API provides a method to enumerate the available gesture-capable input
devices (including the dynamic appearance and disappearance of such devices) and
a way to specify a subset of these devices for use in a particular gesture
detection instance.  A client application might typically respond to gestures
from any input device, but others, such as a drawing application, may wish to
bypass gesture detection on, for example, a drawing tablet while accepting them
from a touchscreen for other functions such as zoom and rotate.</p><p>GEIS uses a set of client-supplied callbacks to report the availability of input
devices so that devices that dynamically appear or disappear can be reported
through a consistent interface.</p></div></div></div><div class="section" title="3. GEIS Functions and Errors"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h2 class="title" style="clear: both"><a id="_geis_functions_and_errors"></a>3. GEIS Functions and Errors</h2></div></div></div><div class="section" title="3.1. Errors"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_errors"></a>3.1. Errors</h3></div></div></div><div class="note" title="Note" style="margin-left: 0; margin-right: 10%;"><table border="0" summary="Note"><tr><td rowspan="2" align="center" valign="top" width="25"><img alt="[Note]" src="/etc/asciidoc/images/icons//note.png" /></td><th align="left"></th></tr><tr><td align="left" valign="top"><p>This section is not complete.</p></td></tr></table></div><p>GEIS functions usually return a status code indicating success or failure.  The
status codes that may be returned, and their meanings, are as follows.</p><div class="variablelist"><dl><dt><span class="term">

<code class="literal">GEIS_SUCCESS</code>
</span></dt><dd>
  Normal, successful completion of the function.
</dd><dt><span class="term">
<code class="literal">GEIS_BAD_ARGUMENT</code>
</span></dt><dd>
  One or more argument values are invalid.  Any command taking parameters may
  generate this error.
</dd><dt><span class="term">
<code class="literal">GEIS_STATUS_NOT_SUPPORTED</code>
</span></dt><dd>
  An operation or configuration item is not supported by the implementation.

</dd><dt><span class="term">
<code class="literal">GEIS_UNKNOWN_ERROR</code>
</span></dt><dd>
  A general catchall error:  an error occurred that is not covered by any other
  defined status code.
</dd></dl></div></div><div class="section" title="3.2. Initialization"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_initialization"></a>3.2. Initialization</h3></div></div></div><div class="note" title="Note" style="margin-left: 0; margin-right: 10%;"><table border="0" summary="Note"><tr><td rowspan="2" align="center" valign="top" width="25"><img alt="[Note]" src="/etc/asciidoc/images/icons//note.png" /></td><th align="left"></th></tr><tr><td align="left" valign="top"><p>This section is not complete.</p></td></tr></table></div><p>A GEIS instance may be initialized by calling</p><pre class="programlisting">GeisStatus geis_init(GeisWinInfo *win_info, GeisInstance *geis_instance);</pre><p><code class="literal">GEIS_SUCCESS</code> is returned on success and <span class="emphasis"><em>geis_instance</em></span> is updated with an
instance value to be used in subsequent GEIS calls.</p><p>The definition of the <code class="literal">GeisWinInfo</code> fields is entirely dependant on the
implementation.  For example, an X11-based gesture recognizer may specify the

<span class="emphasis"><em>window_id</em></span> as the <span class="emphasis"><em>win_info</em></span> argument.</p></div><div class="section" title="3.3. Configuration and Control"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_configuration_and_control"></a>3.3. Configuration and Control</h3></div></div></div><p>A particular GEIS implementation may support a subset of standard configuarable
items and, in addition, zero or more implementation-specific configuration
items.  The implementation-specific configuration items will be documented by
the implementation.</p><p>To determine of a confiuration item is supported, use the following call.</p><pre class="programlisting">GeisStatus geis_configuration_supported(GeisInstance instance,
                                        int          configuration_item);</pre><p>This function will return <code class="literal">GEIS_STATUS_SUCCESS</code> if the <span class="emphasis"><em>configuration_item</em></span> is
supported by the implementation, <code class="literal">GEIS_STATUS_NOT_SUPPORTED</code> otherwise.</p><p>The following standard configuration items must be available.
.Input Standard Configuration Items</p><div class="informaltable"><table cellpadding="4px" style="border-collapse: collapse;border-top: 3px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 3px solid #527bbd; " width="60%"><colgroup><col /><col /></colgroup><thead><tr><th style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"><code class="literal">configuration item</code> </th><th style="border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"> description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"><p>GEIS_CONFIG_UNIX_FD</p></td><td style="" align="left" valign="top"><p>A posix descriptor for event loop synchronization is available.</p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p>Configuration-specifc values may be set and retrieved using the following calls.</p><pre class="programlisting">GeisStatus geis_configuration_get_value(GeisInstance instance,
                                        int          configuration_item,
                                        void*        value);

GeisStatus geis_configuration_set_value(GeisInstance instance,
                                        int          configuration_item,
                                        void*        value);</pre><p>The actual type and meaning of the <span class="emphasis"><em>value</em></span> argument depends on the

<span class="emphasis"><em>configuration_item</em></span>.  Standard configuration item types are described in the
following table.</p><div class="table"><a id="id2782951"></a><p class="title"><b>Table 1. Input Standard Configuration Item Types</b></p><div class="table-contents"><table summary="Input Standard Configuration Item Types" cellpadding="4px" style="border-collapse: collapse;border-top: 3px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 3px solid #527bbd; " width="60%"><colgroup><col /><col /><col /></colgroup><thead><tr><th style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"><code class="literal">configuration item</code> </th><th style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"> type </th><th style="border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"> description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"><p>GEIS_CONFIG_UNIX_FD</p></td><td style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"><p>int</p></td><td style="" align="left" valign="top"><p>A posix file descriptor</p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><br class="table-break" /><p>Integration with the native event loop is through an implementation-specific
mechanism (likely obtained through the configuration calls above, but documented
more thoroughly in the implementation documentation) combined with a call to the
GEIS dispatch mechanism.</p><pre class="programlisting">GeisStatus geis_event_dispatch(geisInstance instance);</pre></div><div class="section" title="3.4. Input Devices"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_input_devices_2"></a>3.4. Input Devices</h3></div></div></div><p>Gestures are associated with input devices (a gesture must be input on a
device).  Client software may subscribe to gestures that occur on all input
devices or on only a subset of input devices.  For that to be possible, the
client needs to enumerate all available input devices.  In addition, many input
devices have a dynamic lifetime — they may be added or removed asynchronously.
the client software needs to be made aware that new input devices have become
available or existing devices have become unavailable.</p><p>GEIS input device enumeration and availability notification is performed through
the following interface.</p><pre class="programlisting">typedef unsigned int GeisInputDeviceId;

typedef void (*GeisInputCallback)(void             *cookie,
                                  GeisInputDeviceId device_id,
                                  void             *attrs);

typedef struct GeisInputFuncs
{
  GeisInputCallback  added;   /**&lt; Receives new input device notices */
  GeisInputCallback  changed; /**&lt; Receives modified input device notices */
  GeisInputCallback  removed; /**&lt; Receives removes input device notices */

} GeisInputFuncs;

GeisStatus geis_input_devices(GeisInstance    geis_instance,
                              GeisInputFuncs  funcs,
                              void           *cookie);</pre><p>The API provides a list of available input devices one at a time through the
client-supplied <span class="emphasis"><em>added</em></span> callback function.</p><p>The <span class="emphasis"><em>changed</em></span> callback function or the <span class="emphasis"><em>removed</em></span> callback function may be
invoked at any time after <span class="strong"><strong>geis_input_devices</strong></span> is called and before

<span class="strong"><strong>geis_finish</strong></span> is called to tear down the <code class="literal">GeisInstance</code> or <span class="strong"><strong>geis_input_devices</strong></span>
is called again to replace the callback function.  This can occur when input
devices are, for example, physically connected to or disconnected from the
system.</p><p>The <span class="emphasis"><em>cookie</em></span> value passed to <span class="strong"><strong>geis_input_devices</strong></span> is passed unmodified to
callback function.  Client programs may use this for passing context-specific
information into the callback.</p><p>The suggested behaviour of an implementation is to invoke the <span class="emphasis"><em>callback</em></span> for
each input device known at call time <span class="emphasis"><em>before</em></span> returning from the

<span class="strong"><strong>geis_input_devices</strong></span> call.</p></div><div class="section" title="3.5. Subscribing to Gestures"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_subscribing_to_gestures"></a>3.5. Subscribing to Gestures</h3></div></div></div><p>Gestures are specific to a <code class="literal">GeisInstance</code> and set of input devices.  The
<code class="literal">GeisInstance</code> must be informed of the set of gestures (and input devices) of
interest.</p><pre class="programlisting">typedef unsigned int GeisGestureType;
typedef unsigned int GeisGestureId;

typedef void (*GeisGestureCallback)(void             *cookie,
                                    GeisGestureType   gesture_type,
                                    GeisGestureId     gesture_id,
                                    GeisSize          attr_count,
                                    GeisGestureAttr  *attrs);

typedef struct GeisGestureFuncs
{
  GeisGestureCallback  added;
  GeisGestureCallback  removed;
  GeisGestureCallback  start;
  GeisGestureCallback  update;
  GeisGestureCallback  finish;
} GeisGestureFuncs;

GeisStatus geis_subscribe(GeisInstance        geis_instance,
                          GeisInputDeviceId  *input_list,
                          const char*        *gesture_list,
                          GeisGestureFuncs    funcs,
                          void               *cookie);

GeisStatus geis_unsubscribe(GeisInstance     geis_instance,
                            GeisGestureType *gesture_list);</pre><p>The client supplies a list of input devices (or the constant
<code class="literal">GEIS_ALL_INPUT_DEVICES</code>) and a <code class="literal">NULL</code> terminated list of C-style strings naming
the gestures to be recognized.  The constant <code class="literal">GEIS_ALL_GESTURES</code> indicates all
available gestures should be detected.</p><p>GEIS provides a list of gestures available in the desired window and input
device(s) one at a time through the client-supplied <span class="emphasis"><em>added</em></span> callback function
with the <code class="literal">GEIS_GESTURE_TYPE_ADDED</code> action.  This allows the client to build a
map of gesture names to <code class="literal">GeisGestureType</code>.  If the recognition engine does not
support a named gesture type passed to <span class="strong"><strong>geis_subscribe</strong></span> then no

<code class="literal">GeisGestureType</code> is passed to the callback function for the named gesture.</p><p>The <span class="emphasis"><em>cookie</em></span> value passed to <span class="strong"><strong>geis_subscribe</strong></span> is passed unmodified to
<span class="emphasis"><em>callback</em></span>.  Client programs may use this for passing context-specific
information into the callback.</p></div><div class="section" title="3.6. Receiving Gestures"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_receiving_gestures"></a>3.6. Receiving Gestures</h3></div></div></div><p>One of the gesture event callback functions may be invoked at any time after
<span class="strong"><strong>geis_input_devices</strong></span> is called and before <span class="strong"><strong>geis_finish</strong></span> is called to tear down
the <code class="literal">GeisInstance</code> or <span class="strong"><strong>geis_input_devices</strong></span> is called again to replace the

<span class="emphasis"><em>callback</em></span> function.  This can occur when input devices are, for example,
physically connected to or disconnected from the system.</p><p>Most gestures will result in a <span class="emphasis"><em>start</em></span> callback, zero or more <span class="emphasis"><em>update</em></span>
callbacks, and a <span class="emphasis"><em>finish</em></span> callback.  Some gestures such as <span class="emphasis"><em>tap</em></span> gestures may
result in only a single <span class="emphasis"><em>update</em></span> callback.  This behaviour is dependent on the
underlying gesture recognition engine</p><p>Once a gesture is recognized, a <code class="literal">GEIS_GESTURE_STARTED</code> action is sent. A set of
zero or more attributes will be returned.  These attributes are specific to the
gesture.  Depending on the nature of the gesture, one or more

<code class="literal">GEIS_GESTURE_UPDATED</code> actions may be sent, and finally a
<code class="literal">GEIS_GESTURE_FINISHED</code> action will be sent.  Each of these may or may not have
a set of attributes associated.</p><p>A gesture or gesture type action is often associated with a set of attributes.
These attributes are delivered to the callback function as a read-only array of
<span class="emphasis"><em>GeisGestureAttr</em></span> type, defined below.</p><pre class="programlisting">typedef struct GeisGestureAttr
{
  GeisString   name;
  GeisAttrType type;
  union
  {
    GeisBoolean boolean_val;
    GeisFloat   float_val;
    GeisInteger integer_val;
    GeisString  string_val;
  };
} GeisGestureAttr;</pre></div><div class="section" title="3.7. Recognizer Teardown"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_recognizer_teardown"></a>3.7. Recognizer Teardown</h3></div></div></div><p>Teardown of the gesture recognition session is accomplished by the <span class="strong"><strong>geis_finish</strong></span>
function.</p><pre class="programlisting">GeisStatus geis_finish(GeisInstance *geis_instance);</pre><p>This function frees any allocated resources associated with <span class="emphasis"><em>geis_instance</em></span>.  It
does not affect other instances.</p><p>All resources are expected to be freed automatically on process termination.
The <span class="strong"><strong>geis_finish</strong></span> function is not expected to return any status value other than

<code class="literal">GEIS_SUCCESS</code>.</p></div></div><div class="section" title="4. Standard Gestures"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h2 class="title" style="clear: both"><a id="_standard_gestures"></a>4. Standard Gestures</h2></div></div></div><p>A limited number of fundamental gestures are expected to be supplied with the
API.  All implementations are expected to support at least this set of
predefined gestures.  Additional predefined gestures and user- or
application-defined gestures are beyond the scope of this specification but are
expected to be made available by the implementation.</p><div class="table"><a id="id2798294"></a><p class="title"><b>Table 2. Predefined Gestures</b></p><div class="table-contents"><table summary="Predefined Gestures" cellpadding="4px" style="border-collapse: collapse;border-top: 3px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 3px solid #527bbd; " width="60%"><colgroup><col /><col /><col /></colgroup><thead><tr><th style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top">gesture name </th><th style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top">symbolic name        </th><th style="border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top">description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"><p>Drag</p></td><td style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"><p>GEIS_GESTURE_DRAG</p></td><td style="border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"><p></p></td></tr><tr><td style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"><p>Pinch</p></td><td style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"><p>GEIS_GESTURE_PINCH</p></td><td style="border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top"><p></p></td></tr><tr><td style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; Common Attributes"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_common_attributes"></a>4.1. Common Attributes</h3></div></div></div><p>All standard gestures provide a common set of attributes.</p><div class="table"><a id="id2797174"></a><p class="title"><b>Table 3. Common Gesture Attributes</b></p><div class="table-contents"><table summary="Common Gesture Attributes" cellpadding="4px" style="border-collapse: collapse;border-top: 3px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 3px solid #527bbd; " width="60%"><colgroup><col /><col /><col /></colgroup><thead><tr><th style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; border-bottom: 1px solid #527bbd; " align="left" valign="top">name                                    </th><th style="border-right: 1px solid #527bbd; GEIS Versioning, Header Files, and Constants"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h2 class="title" style="clear: both"><a id="_geis_versioning_header_files_and_constants"></a>5. GEIS Versioning, Header Files, and Constants</h2></div></div></div><p>Each published version of GEIS supports the specified client API of that
version and all prior versions of those APIs (backwards compatibility).</p><div class="section" title="5.1. Header Files"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_header_files"></a>5.1. Header Files</h3></div></div></div><p>The GEIS specification defines an ISO C language binding.  The GEIS header file

<code class="literal">&lt;geis/geis.h&gt;</code> provides prototypes for all GEIS entry points and C preprocessors
for all GEIS tokens, for use both by client code and implementers.</p><p>Languages other than C and C++ will define GEIS interfaces using other methods
outside the scope of this specification.</p></div><div class="section" title="5.2. Compile-time Version Detection"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_compile_time_version_detection"></a>5.2. Compile-time Version Detection</h3></div></div></div><p>To allow code to be written portably against future GEIS versions, the
compile-time environment must make it possible to determine which GEIS version
interface are available.  For C and C++ code the <code class="literal">&lt;geis/geis.h&gt;</code> header defined C
preprocessor symbols corresponding to all versions of GEIS supported by the
implementation.</p><pre class="programlisting">#define GEIS_VERSION_1_0  1</pre><p>Future versions of GEIS will define additional preprocessor symbols
corresponding to the major and minor numbers of those versions.</p></div><div class="section" title="5.3. Constants and Implementation-Supplied Values"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h3 class="title"><a id="_constants_and_implementation_supplied_values"></a>5.3. Constants and Implementation-Supplied Values</h3></div></div></div><p>Constants and enumerator values for GEIS tokens defined in this specification are
required to be common across all implementations.  A reference version of the
<code class="literal">geis.h</code> header file can be downloaded from <span class="strong"><strong>to be determined</strong></span>.</p><p>All implementation-specific types, values, and macros used in <code class="literal">geis.h</code> are
partitioned into an implementation header, <code class="literal">geisimpl.h</code>, which is automatically6
included by <code class="literal">geis.h</code>.  Implementers should need only modify <code class="literal">geisimpl.h</code>, never

<code class="literal">geis.h</code>.</p></div></div><div class="section" title="6. Conformance Testing for Implementers"><div class="titlepage"><div><div><h2 class="title" style="clear: both"><a id="_conformance_testing_for_implementers"></a>6. Conformance Testing for Implementers</h2></div></div></div><div class="note" title="Note" style="margin-left: 0; margin-right: 10%;"><table border="0" summary="Note"><tr><td rowspan="2" align="center" valign="top" width="25"><img alt="[Note]" src="/etc/asciidoc/images/icons//note.png" /></td><th align="left"></th></tr><tr><td align="left" valign="top"><p>This section is not complete.</p></td></tr></table></div></div></div>
</pre>
